info.game_comments:
2002 College Championship semifinal game 2.
From the Schottenstein Center at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

(1, 1).clue: This president was nicknamed "The Pen of the American Revolution"

(2, 1).clue: This billiard ball is named for the stick that strikes it

(3, 1).clue: This 4-letter word can mean "stop"; while pouring you a drink someone might ask you to "say" it

(4, 1).clue: In Genesis 28, Jacob dreams of one of these reaching to heaven

(5, 1).clue: It's the year in which the U.S. will celebrate its tricentennial

(1, 2).clue: In 1794 Aaron Burr formally introduced this fourth president to his future first lady

(2, 2).clue: In the 9-wicket version of this game, the ball goes through a pair of wickets before it hits the stake

(3, 2).clue: "Going to the fair", Simple Simon asked the pieman, "Let me taste your" this

(4, 2).clue: Stephen Collins, seen here, plays Rev. Eric Camden on this popular series

(5, 2).clue: In the U.S. in 2000 it was 74.1 for men & 79.5 for women

(6, 2).clue: Concentrate on the color coral or rose

(1, 3).clue: He signed the Declaration of Independence twice: on July 4, 1776 & in large letters the following month

(2, 3).clue: In 2000 Gabrielle Reece, training for the LPGA, traded this ball for a golf ball

(3, 3).clue: In Spanish, this letter is "I griega"

(4, 3).clue: In Islamic tradition, Muhammad is taken to heaven on a magical horselike creature by this angel

(5, 3).clue: According to the proverb, it "saves nine"

(6, 3).clue: War between the Herefords & the Guernseys

(1, 4).clue: "Common Sense" author whose will read, "I die in perfect composure and resignation to the will of my creator"

(2, 4).clue: A small ball is involved in this game that uses the layout seen here

(3, 4).clue: Term for a Buddhist temple, there's a big one in Angkor

(4, 4).clue: The death of this silent film idol, seen here, inspired the 1926 song "There's a New Star in Heaven Tonight"

(5, 4).clue: Traditionally, sabbatical leave, which teachers take for study or travel, comes once every this many years

(6, 4).clue: A poorly lit place to lift weights & do the treadmill

(1, 5).clue: He knew "not what course others may take", but his course was to serve as Virginia governor, 1776-79 & 1784-86

(2, 5).clue: The USHA promotes this sport whose court may have a glass back & sides for you to watch

(3, 5).clue: In the American Revolution, last name of British admiral Richard & his brother, general William

(4, 5).clue: "A man's reach should exceed his grasp, or what's a heaven for?" is from his poem "Andrea del Sarto"

(5, 5).clue: In English, it's the only day of the week that's named for a Roman god

(1, 1).clue: Lesbos & the Cyclades are found in this sea

(2, 1).clue: This comedienne who has hosted the Oscars has also been the center square on "Hollywood Squares"

(3, 1).clue: Atoms of this abundant element are the smallest & simplest known

(4, 1).clue: Native Americans made canoes up to 45 feet long from the bark of the paper type of this tree

(5, 1).clue: In 1932 Julian Huxley wrote "A Scientist Among the Soviets" & his brother Aldous published this novel

(6, 1).clue: In this poem, Lewis Carroll invented such words as mimsy, a combination of flimsy & miserable

(1, 2).clue: It's about 50 miles across the Adriatic Sea from Italy to this country on the Balkan Peninsula

(2, 2).clue: He's the big daddy seen here

(3, 2).clue: This element, whose name means "greenish-yellow", is used to make laundry clean & bright

(4, 2).clue: If you're sugaring off, you're taking advantage of natural sweets from this tree

(5, 2).clue: These siblings enthrall us with their memoirs: Malachy wrote "A Monk Swimming" & Frank wrote "Angela's Ashes"

(6, 2).clue: This French word originally meant "a place where one docks" a boat, not a car

(1, 3).clue: It's paired with Barbuda in the name of a Caribbean island country

(2, 3).clue: The Little Tramp was one of the classic silent movie characters created by this popular comedic actor

(3, 3).clue: Galena is the chief ore for getting this element, atomic number 82, out

(4, 3).clue: Add 4 letters to "palm" to get this palm that has Texas & Louisiana types

(5, 3).clue: These brothers were so close that Jakob lived in the same home with Wilhelm even after Wilhelm got married in 1825

(6, 3).clue: Used to fortell the future, this game's name is derived from the French & German words for "yes"

(1, 4).clue: It's the highest mountain in the Western Hemisphere

(2, 4).clue: A standup comedian from the age of 16, in 2002 she finished up a 6-year stint as a daytime TV talk show host

(3, 4).clue: Sn, the symbol for this metallic element, comes from its Latin name, stannum

(4, 4).clue: 3-letter trees include elm, oak & this olive family member used for furniture & baseball bats

(5, 4).clue: This man who chronicles the rich, famous & criminal for Vanity Fair is a brother of novelist John Gregory Dunne

(6, 4).clue: This term for one who explores caves comes from a Greek word for "cave"

(1, 5).clue: It's the city in Uttar Pradesh where Shah Jahan built a memorial to his wife Mumtaz Mahal

(2, 5).clue: Last names of 1940s & '50s comedy team Bud & Lou

(3, 5).clue: This metallic element that's last alphabetically is used to make the cores of nuclear reactors

(4, 5).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports)  From the Latin, the name of this type of pine comes from its heavy mass

(5, 5).clue: Thomas Trollope wrote many books, but he's less famous than this brother who wrote "Barchester Towers"

(6, 5).clue: Over 800 years old, this 6-letter Middle English word meaning "track" was first used for a detective in 1872

(0, 0).clue: So far some of its major components are Zarya, Unity, Zvezda & Canadarm2
